headline: Warner Bros Discovery sees activist Sachem Head increase stake in Q4
summary: Warner Bros. Discovery attracted the attention of activist investor Sachem Head Capital Management in the ‌fourth quarter when the media and entertainment giant agreed to sell ‌its streaming and studios business to Netflix, according to a regulatory filing on Friday.  Sachem Head, one ​of last year's best-performing hedge funds, said in the Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it more than doubled its holding in Warner Bros. Discovery to own nearly 8 million shares at the end of the fourth quarter.  The company, which ‌has a market value ⁠of roughly $70 billion, ranked among Sachem Head's 10 biggest investments in U.S. stocks at the end of last year.

headline: Analysts See 55% Upside for Netflix Despite $77 Share Price
summary: As shares of Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) have fallen more than 6% this week, retail investor sentiment on platforms like Reddit and X has shifted noticeably. The stock now trades at ~$76.88, down 26% over the past year and 18% year-to-date. On a pre-split basis, Netflix has tumbled from around $1,323 in June 2025 to an equivalent ... Analysts See 55% Upside for Netflix Despite $77 Share Price

headline: 13 Press Releases You Need to See This Week
summary: With thousands of press releases published each week, it can be difficult to keep up with everything on PR Newswire. headline: Netflix Faces Warner Bros. Discovery Battle And Valuation Questions
summary: Netflix (NasdaqGS:NFLX) has made an US$82.7b bid to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery, triggering a takeover contest. Paramount Skydance has submitted a rival all cash offer that includes a ticking fee and breakup fee coverage. Activist investor Ancora Holdings has built a large stake in Warner Bros. Discovery and is urging shareholders to back Paramount Skydance's proposal over Netflix's. The U.S. Department of Justice has opened an antitrust investigation into Netflix focused on potential...

headline: 3 Unpopular Stocks Walking a Fine Line
summary: Wall Street has issued downbeat forecasts for the stocks in this article. These predictions are rare - financial institutions typically hesitate to say bad things about a company because it can jeopardize their other revenue-generating business lines like M&A advisory.
